awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Molecular Basis Of Novel Phenotypes Resulting From Interpopulation Hybridization
awd_abstract_narration:
Climate change affects the geographic distribution of populations and species and can result in increased opportunities for hybridization between previously isolated populations.  Hybridization can have a range of outcomes.  Most frequently, hybridization results in loss of fitness (hybrid breakdown), effectively reducing interbreeding and promoting the formation of new species. Occasionally, however, novel combinations of genes yield ecological advantages to hybrids, including adaptation to new ecological niches.  What attributes of parental populations predict the outcome of hybridization? Answering this question is the focus of this project, and will provide new insights into the effects of climate and ecological changes on adaptation rates and species formation. The researchers also will engage in novel public informal education at the Birch Aquarium and in hands-on experiences in marine biology for 5th grade students in underserved San Diego neighborhoods. 

Predicting hybridization outcomes requires an understanding of the molecular basis of hybrid phenotypes. This project will conduct genomic analyses of hybrids produced by crosses between divergent populations of the copepod Tigriopus californicus.  Previous work has shown that energy production by mitochondria is frequently disrupted in hybrids.  Whole genome sequencing will be used to determine genetic differences between groups of hybrid copepods with normal versus disrupted mitochondrial performance; differentiation between the groups will identify candidate genes that are potentially responsible for hybrid breakdown. Results will address: a) Does hybridization result in widespread incompatibilities across the genome, or can targeted genes be identified? b) Are the same genomic regions responsible for hybrid breakdown in different interpopulation crosses?  A similar approach will be used to examine the genomic basis of improved hybrid thermal tolerance.  What genetic interactions allow some hybrids to survive temperatures that are lethal to both parental populations?  Is hybrid performance predictable from genetic or ecological differences between parental populations?

por.por_cntn:
Geographically isolated populations may become differentiated from each other with respect to their morphological, behavioral, and physiological traits as a result of natural selection and genetic drift. These evolutionary forces work on genetic mutations that accumulate within each population, but that are not shared because of reduced migration. When such populations are distributed across wide latitudes, they will often evolve very different levels of many traits, including traits important for dealing with high temperature stressors that are becoming more common via global climate change. Interestingly, when divergent populations are able to interbreed, their offspring often display traits that give them a wide variation of fitness, with some individuals having lower fitness than their parents (termed 'breakdown') and others with higher fitness. In this project, our main objective was to understand the ecological and genetic conditions that promote adaptation to different environments and that result in hybrids with extreme levels of fitness.

All of our work focused on the tidepool copepod Tigriopus californicus, a minute crustacean that inhabits the splash zone of rocky coasts from Baja, Mexico, to Alaska. This species can be easily collected and cultured in lab, where physiological and genetic experiments can be performed on wild-type populations and hybrids created in the lab. Our experiments combined several phenotypic assays (measures of tolerance to heat stress, assays for rates of ATP synthesis, and quantification of gene expression) with genomic and computational analyses. In brief, our primary findings were: (1) populations as close as 8 km from each other evolved distinct mechanisms of dealing with high heat stress. While both populations are tolerant to high temperatures, they appear to rely of slightly different sets of genes to help their cells maintain physiological performance and survive; (2) metabolic rates vary widely among copepod populations as they deal with high temperatures. Some populations elevate their metabolic rates when temperatures increase, which is expected. However, other populations maintain the same metabolic rates across many levels of temperature; (3) among hybrid individuals, those that grow fast (a measure of high fitness) tend to produce more ATP in their cells. Moreover, fast-growing individuals have nuclear genes that were inherited from the same population as their mitochondria. This 'matching' of nuclear and mitochondrial genomes is thought to allow cells to produce ATP more efficiently than individuals with more mixed or mismatched genomes.

 Overall, results from this project improve our understanding of which genetic tools organisms rely on in the process of adaptation to environmental stressors. They also show that metabolic fitness can be dependent on how well-matched the nuclear and mitochondrial genomes are, and that hybridization between geographically isolated populations generate a wide diversity of genomic combinations that range from highly matched to highly mismatched. This set of conclusions has implications across many fields, from consequences of animal migration due to climate change to human mitochondrial replacement therapy.

In addition to the broader impacts to marine biology and evolution, grant funds also supported outreach and training opportunities. Trainees supported by this award were 1 postdoctoral scholar, 1 PhD student, and 8 undergraduate students. The trainees encompassed a diversity of backgrounds and identities, with 7 being women and 3 from underrepresented groups. Results from the funded project were communicated in local, national, and international conferences across the award period, for a total 8 presentations. Finally, our research group worked closely with the local chapter of the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) to provide training and hands-on experiences in marine genetics research. With LSAMP, we developed and ran workshops for training first-year and transfer students in basic molecular techniques, with the aim of preparing them for research experiences during their undergraduate degree. We also recruited undergraduate research assistants through LSAMP, and these students became a full member of our team for several academic terms.
